author: @omernauer123
text: For people working on this in 2024 and are contemplating where to move the app.app_context().push().  I put it inside the def create_app:  ------------------------------------------------------------ def create_app(config_class=Config):     app = Flask(__name__)     app.config.from_object(Config)      db.init_app(app)     app.app_context().push()     bcrypt.init_app(app)     login_manager.init_app(app)     mail.init_app(app)

author: @andrei31112
text: If you happen to delete the site.db and want to add your own db, you can add the following code to your run.py:  from flaskblog import create_app from flaskblog import db  app = create_app()  with app.app_context():     db.create_all()     db.session.commit()  if __name__ == '__main__':     app.run(debug=True)  My rationale for adding this to the run.py is the following (and I might the wrong). The app is created using the factory pattern: since we use app_context(), the db is created within the context correct app. You could run this inside the __init__.py, but you will get circular import references so you would have to do ugly imports at the bottom of the __init__.py just before return app.   If there is no file called site.db in your flaskblog folder, the above code will create it. If there is a site.db file, it will ignore the code. If you don't initialize the db after creating the app, your app will crash when you call it in the browser as the following statement in the home route cannot execute on an empty posts table.      posts = Post.query.order_by(         Post.date_posted.desc()).paginate(page=page, per_page=5)   The error you will get without the db initialization added to run.py is the following:  sqlalchemy.exc.OperationalError: (sqlite3.OperationalError) no such table: post [SQL: SELECT post.id AS post_id, post.title AS post_title, post.date_posted AS post_date_posted, post.content AS post_content, post.user_id AS post_user_id  FROM post ORDER BY post.date_posted DESC  LIMIT ? OFFSET ?] [parameters: (5, 0)] (Background on this error at: https://sqlalche.me/e/14/e3q8)  You could probably also condition on the posts table being available and then pass on empty posts to the template in your home route, if the condition is not met, but I think it's not required or not as clean.

author: @EmiliaKaida
text: Just for this episode, one really confusing thing for me is WHY he used environment variable in an OS scope. Usually env variables should be scoped to app (because for example we might have many Flask apps running on the same system -> name clashing etc... Also, it's a best practice in other frameworks like Spring boot or Node JS) It just seems so weird for him to do it this way. Could be really confusing for beginners.

author: @RonBertino
text: I think there's a code error in flaskbog/__init__.py  On line 17 you're passing in the Config class as a default argument to the create_app function. def create_app(config_class=Config)  On line 19 you're then telling Flask the config that it should be using: app.config.from_object(Config)  You'll notice that you seem to have hard-coded the Config on line 19, rather than using the config_class argument. This implies that if you were try to launch a different instance of the application, with alternate configuration data, the current code would ignore this new config since it's hard-coded to the Config class.

author: @Shadowless_Kick
text: I find a small issue in this lesson and need your confirmation or clarification: The file __init__.py has the following 4 lines of code:       from flaskblog.config import Config       def create_app(config_class=Config):             app = Flask(__name__)             app.config.from_object(Config) Argument config_class is not used by function create_app, if we change the second line above to       def create_app(): or change the 4th line above to       app.config.from_object(config_class)  the code is cleaner and the app still works.   Am I right or I missed something? Thank you for this great tutorial.

author: @jiizzyy01
text: I got this error:  RuntimeError: Working outside of application context.  This typically means that you attempted to use functionality that needed to interface with the current application object in some way. To solve this, set up an application context with app.app_context().  See the documentation for more information.  And solved it doing this:  defÂ create_app(config_class=Config): Â Â Â Â appÂ =Â Flask(__name__)  Â Â Â Â withÂ app.app_context(): Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â app.config.from_object(Config)  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â db.init_app(app) Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â bcrypt.init_app(app) Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â login_manager.init_app(app) Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â mail.init_app(app)  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â fromÂ myapp.users.routesÂ importÂ users Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â fromÂ myapp.products.routesÂ importÂ products Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â fromÂ myapp.orders.routesÂ importÂ orders Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â fromÂ myapp.main.routesÂ importÂ main Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â fromÂ myapp.errors.handlersÂ importÂ errors Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â app.register_blueprint(users) Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â app.register_blueprint(products) Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â app.register_blueprint(orders) Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â app.register_blueprint(main) Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â app.register_blueprint(errors)   Â Â Â Â returnÂ app   https://flask.palletsprojects.com/en/1.1.x/appcontext/

Those Flask tutoriais should start with blueprints from step one, so people wouldn't go through hell like I did.

author: @heisenburgfreed7591
text: After I added below os environment variables:      SECRET_KEY = os.environ.get('SECRET_KEY')     SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI = os.environ.get('SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI') into .bash_profile I ran immediately using python run.py, it could enter the debug mode, but when I opened Chrome, and visit localhost:5000, it shows error in the debug mode like this:     AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'drivername' I checked over and over, compared all the codes that this tutorial required to change, nothing is wrong. Then I checked Stack Overflow with the link: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/58468775/sqlalchemy-nonetype-object-has-no-attribute-drivername And I just restarted my computer, then all act normal.  It seems when I updated the .bash_profile, the MAC hasn't activate those os environment variables in time. So to restart the MAC actually fixed the issue.  Sharing the experience with all you guys.

author: @stanly19981005
text: for anyone who's unable to use db.create_all() in your terminal after switching to application factory structure, I have found a solution. You might receive an error message like  Traceback (most recent call last):   File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module> NameError: name 'db' is not defined The problem is that your terminal has not yet configured a shell context. I might not be the best person to explain. You can check the following 2 links that I have spent hours looking for.  https://blog.miguelgrinberg.com/post/the-flask-mega-tutorial-part-iv-database/page/7 https://github.com/miguelgrinberg/microblog/blob/master/microblog.py Basically, you just add this code snippet to the script that you import your application package and run the app, for example, run.py. from app import create_app, db, cli from app.models import User, Post, Message, Notification, Task  app = create_app() cli.register(app)  #this part is the magic @app.shell_context_processor def make_shell_context():     return {'db': db, 'User': User, 'Post': Post, 'Message': Message,             'Notification': Notification, 'Task': Task} hope that helps ease your headache while debugging

author: @hansjoachimhueskemann4742
text: At about minute 32:30 after Corey moved the "app..." and the "app.config..." lines into his create_app function he should make one change in the line "app.config..."-line. He should set the value "Config" to "config_class". After that the line reads:  "app.config.from_object(config_class)" If he misses this, he cannot use different configurations when calling the run.py funktion. He will always use "Config" instead

Still these are GREAT videos and many  thanks to you for creating them.

author: @mattholland0202
text: Just in case anyone else comes across a similar issue: setting the environment variables didn't work straight away for me.  I found that I specifically had to run "export NAME='value'" for both of them in the Terminal window I was launching the app from, then it worked fine.  I imagine there was something that hadn't restarted to pull in the new profile/variables etc, but I found this to be the quickest solution rather than try to track that down.

author: @yalgret
text: I spent about 30min learning regular expressions using Google (duck duck go for privacy :) ), which was very useful for the find and replace to update the url_for() usage! I recommend this as it's now a powerful tool I have for use in future programming challenges!   I used: url_for[\(]'[[:alnum:]]*'  and;  url_for[\(]'[[:alnum:]]*.[[:alnum:]]*'  These two find either; the original form of the function before part 11, and, the new form with an added object (and connecting dot).     I'm using Notepad++ which has regular expression search. Use google to learn regular expressions for your particular editor.   EDIT: my expressions missed out functions that had underscores in them. It's easily fixed though once you know the syntax.

author: @zesty-lemur
text: For anybody using VSCode, when it comes to updating the routes, do yourself a favour and make use of the Find & Replace using Regex function.   Using Find with "url_for\('((?!main|posts|user|static))" will give you a list of all the outstanding routes you need to change (once you change them, it'll stop detecting them.   With a bit of imagination, you could also use F&R w/ Regex to pick out (for example) all the 'main' routes and change them to include 'main'.   Enjoy!

author: @ian_senior
text: you can also ignore directories when using the tree command by using the -I switch (that is a capital i like in ice).  Use the | (pipe character) to separate multiple directories.  for example, i use this one listed below to ignore pycache and profile pics directories:   tree -I '__pycache__|profile_pics'

author: @howards5205
text: I'm glad how these tutorial series first showed us how to create the app without using blueprints, and later, showed us how to utilize blueprints. I've seen some other tutorials where they started out with blueprints and adopted a complicated application factory paradigm. They were all following good practices, but at the time, I didn't understand WHY they were doing the things they were doing. In these tutorial series, seeing first-hand how the application grows, I was able to see WHY it's necessary to use blueprints and adopt the application factory paradigm. These tutorials are truly awesome!

author: @lightninginmyhands4878
text: FYI init_app() - this method is written inside each extension. The init_app method exists so that the extension object (e.g. flask_login object) can be instantiated without requiring an app object.  http://flask.pocoo.org/docs/1.0/extensiondev/

author: @Existinginthespace
text: ASYNCHRONOUS MAIL Is this a proper way to convert your mail function to be asynchronous?  I was running into this error "No application found. Either work inside a view function or push an application context." when trying to access the mail module in a thread.  I couldn't figure out how to pass the current application to a thread without creating it again. Using the website suggestion below, I defined a minimal mail_app def to pass the application to a thread.   http://flask.pocoo.org/docs/1.0/appcontext/  in yourapp's root "__init__.py " I added the following def --------------------------------------------- START def mail_app(config_class=Config):     app = Flask(__name__)     app.config.from_object(Config)      mail.init_app(app)      return app --------------------------------------------- END  "utils.py" my mail function now looks like so --------------------------------------------- START from threading import Thread from yourapp import mail_app   def send_async_email(msg):     with mail_app().app_context():         mail.send(msg)   def send_alert_email(email):     msg = Message('Test Email', sender='test@test.com', recipients=[email])     msg.body = f'''This is a test email Test successful If you did not make this request then simply ignore this email and no changes will be made. '''      thr = Thread(target=send_async_email, args=[msg])     thr.start() --------------------------------------------- END

author: @slavoie
text: If like me, you ended up wanting to play with the database after making all the changes that Corey did in this video and didn't know what to do, here is a working solution:  1) Make sure to activate the appropriate virtual environment to work with all needed packages. 2) Open a Python interpreter at the root of your project directory (in the same directory as run.py). 3) Execute the following code (without comments if you wish):  from flaskblog import create_app, db app = create_app() # context to run outside the application (no need to launch the server) ctx = app.app_context() ctx.push()  # start working on database after that command # Database manipulations here # ... ctx.pop()  # exit from the app exit()  This explanation comes from StackOverflow here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/24060553/creating-a-database-outside-the-application-context  As explained on that same page at StackOverflow, you could use a "with" block like so: "with app.app_context():" and skip all commands with ctx as shown above, but then you would have to enter everything at once inside the "with" block. If you are going to work directly inside the Python interpreter and not from a script, the first method would be more easy to work with... instead of "with" ;).

author: @jtown4118
text: I enjoyed this video series and look forward to watching more  of your python videos.  For anyone that was confused on how to access your sqlite database tables from the python interpreter to run queries or make modifications after changing the flask app over to blueprints, should now run the following commands listed below inside the python interpreter.    **Make sure you're in your flaskblog directory before invoking the python interpreter to run the commands listed below.  >>> from flaskblog import create_app >>> from flaskblog.__init__ import db >>> from flaskblog.models import current_app, User, Post >>> app = create_app() >>> app.app_context().push() >>> print (app)  # Now you can run queries against your database. >>> User.query.all() >>> Post.query.all()  Also, if you want to utilize a GUI to access your db info instead of using the python interpreter you can use sqlite browser (see link below).  References: http://flask-sqlalchemy.pocoo.org/2.3/contexts/ http://sqlitebrowser.org/

author: @ShanLin03
text: I think your __init__.py didn't include the db.create_all() for clean setup. I suggest adding after  app.register_blueprint(main)  with app.app_context():         db.create_all()  return app
